Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Two Phase Highly Magnetostrictive Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The reorientation of defects can affect technologically important macroscopic properties of solids like hysteresis losses in electric steels. This project will investigate the magnetostriction caused by the reorientation of the magnetization of coherent nano-precipitates of lower symmetry than the host. Iron-cobalt alloys will serve as the model system for the investigation as preliminary microscopic and macroscopic evidence exists in Fe40Co60, which demonstrates that its large magnetostriction, lambda100=200ppm, is due to this mechanism. The insight gained will be used to develop new alloys with enhanced magnetostriction.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The project proposes to investigate the magnetostriction of two phase functional materials, predominantly metallic alloys. Materials displaying low anisotropy and large magnetostriction will be emphasized as they are very suitable for technological applications such as sensors or transducers. Additionally, through this collaborative research, graduate and undergraduate minorities will be trained in materials synthesis and state-of-the-art characterization techniques. The proposed research will increase the competitiveness of minority students in the Science and Engineering disciplines and expand the pool of talented African-American scientists and engineers, who will enlarge the high-technology minority workforce. The planned outreach to Maryland high schools will ensure that the proposed research connects to the potentially interested segment of the high school population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this research program are described below.

- With this funding support, the PI (Dr. Lisfi) and his research partner (Dr. Wuttig) at the University of Maryland have discovered a new family of functional Fe alloys that display the following properties. (1) The materials of interest have a large magnetostriction, a high magnetization, and are rare earth element free. (2) The magnetic anisotropy and the saturation field in these Fe alloys are extremely low. (3) These single crystal materials display a reversible character in response to applied magnetic field. All these characteristics make these alloys very suited for applications such as actuators and magnetic sensors. Moreover, the ongoing investigations on magnetic anisotropy in these alloys will provide knowledge, which will help in gaining insight into the nature of the ferromagnetism of this family of alloys.

 - The PI (Dr. Lisfi) and his research collaborator (Dr. Wuttig) have developed a new method of characterizing defects in magnetic materials. Defects can be present in magnetic materials and can reduce their performances in a broad range of applications such as permanent magnets, data storage and magnetic sensors. The developed method is based on torque magnetometry and has been applied to investigate the magnetism of heterogeneities in ferromagnetic systems. The power of this method is reflected in its ability to measure the magnetization switching, the easy axis alignment, the anisotropy, and the concentration of the magnetic defects.

- Observation for the first time of new stripe magnetic domains confined in mesoscale rectangular structural domains in FePt grown on STO substrate. This magnetic structure displays unique magnetic properties characterized by multiple switching fields.

- Giant perpendicular anisotropy stabilized in epitaxial CFO heterostructures. The anisotropy field of this magnetic structure is estimated to be 70 kOe, whereas its coercivity field is 1T. The origin of this giant out-of-plane anisotropy is the strong lattice distortion of the film.

- The project has enhanced the research infrastructure of Morgan State University (MSU), which is an HBCU, and has provided research opportunities to minority students and faculty from this institution. This has enhanced the broadening participation in magnetic materials to African-Americans, who are underrepresented in this field of science.

- This NSF funding has contributed to an increase of the competitiveness of minority students in the area of magnetic materials at MSU through high quality of education and research training. This has significantly enhanced the opportunities for African-American graduates in the job market.

-This project has helped Morgan State University and the University of Maryland at College Parke to engage in new collaborations and research partnerships.


Last Modified: 04/30/2019
Modified by: Abdellah Lisfi
